content: The "Mental Health Services in Public Health Emergencies Act" allows for grants to states and political subdivisions for mental health services during public health emergencies. The Secretary may grant funds for mental health services during public health emergencies, including crisis counseling and outreach programs for at-risk individuals. The mental health services provided during public health emergencies include crisis counseling, early intervention services, extended therapeutic services for individuals with diagnosed mental health disorders, assessments for the need of extended therapeutic services, and outreach services to inform the public about available resources. The grant recipient must agree to maintain non-Federal expenditures at or above the previous fiscal year's level for authorized activities and cannot use the grant for extended therapeutic services if payment has already been made or is expected. The grant recipient must agree to maintain non-Federal expenditures at or above the previous fiscal year's level for authorized activities and cannot use the grant for extended therapeutic services if payment has already been made or is expected. The grant will not be expended to make payment for mental health services available through emergency response programs. In order to receive a grant for mental health services during public health emergencies, states must develop a statewide plan as per the Secretary's criteria. This plan should include coordination with FEMA and other emergency medical service programs. The grant is administered through state and local mental health agencies. The grant for mental health services during public health emergencies is administered through state and local mental health agencies. Applicants must agree to administer the grant through the responsible state or political subdivision agency. The application for the grant must include a description of intended use and assurance of consistency with the State plan. The grant for mental health services during public health emergencies is administered through state and local mental health agencies. Applicants must coordinate grant activities with other providers, ensure consultation with the State agency, and adhere to a three-year duration limit for payments subject to annual approval and availability of appropriations. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grantees and authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2010, with a limit of 5% for administrative expenses. The Secretary may allocate funds for technical assistance to grantees with a limit of 5% for administrative expenses. SEC. 520L. GRANTS TO STATES FOR STATEWIDE MENTAL HEALTH DISASTER PLANS. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing statewide mental health services plans in response to public health emergencies, training personnel, and other necessary activities. States must include provisions for crisis mental health services in their plans to receive the grant. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing statewide mental health services plans in response to public health emergencies, including crisis counseling, outreach, screening programs, early intervention, extended therapeutic services, needs assessments, case finding, and outreach services for special populations. Coordination with public and private providers of emergency medical services, as well as with Federal, State, and local programs, is required. Additionally, coordination with local educational agencies is necessary. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing statewide mental health services plans in response to public health emergencies, including crisis counseling, outreach, screening programs, early intervention, extended therapeutic services, needs assessments, case finding, and outreach services for special populations. Coordination with public and private providers of emergency medical services, as well as with Federal, State, and local programs, is required. Additionally, providing information and education to the public during public health emergencies and at other times regarding the statewide plan, and designating the State official responsible for administering the plan are key components. Authorization of $65,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 is provided for this purpose. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a National Mental Health Crisis Response Technical Assistance Center. The National Mental Health Crisis Response Technical Assistance Center, established within the Center for Mental Health Services, provides consultation and technical assistance to develop and implement mental health services during public health emergencies. The National Mental Health Crisis Response Technical Assistance Center, established within the Center for Mental Health Services, provides technical expertise on planning, preparedness, and response evaluation activities, develops policy guidelines on mental health concerns related to crisis incidents, conducts training events on mental health needs of disaster victims, serves as a clearinghouse for information on mental health aspects of public health emergencies, and assists States in preparing for behavioral health consequences of terrorism. The Technical Assistance Center, established within the Center for Mental Health Services, may provide onsite expertise during public health emergencies, carry out functions directly or through grants/contracts, and is authorized $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2008-2010. SEC. 5. MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS TRAINING GRANTS. This section amends the Public Health Service Act to include grants for mental health professionals training. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for training mental health professionals in treating disaster victims. Eligible entities must be regional centers of excellence or mental health professional societies. Grants are to be used for training purposes. The Director of the Center for Mental Health Services, in collaboration with other mental health organizations, will develop training materials and procedures for mental health professionals to diagnose and treat individuals affected by disasters. The term 'mental health professional' includes various professionals such as psychiatrists, psychologists, nurses, counselors, and social workers. Authorization of appropriations is provided for mental health professionals to diagnose and treat individuals affected by disasters. This includes social workers, counselors, psychologists, and other licensed professionals. The Secretary may use appropriated funds for program administration.
